name: RBN-4B "Pulsar"
description: The pinnacle of raygun robonaut technology, the Pulsar combines two previously separate instrument lineages into the most powerful single prospecting and ISRU unit ever deployed in the Earth-Moon system. The primary aperture is a fusion-pumped X-ray laser (FXPL): a compact inertial confinement micro-fusion driver (D-T pellet, 100 kJ/shot at 200 Hz) whose resulting X-ray pulse is upconverted and amplified through a gain medium of laser-excited neon-like selenium ions, producing coherent 200 eV soft X-ray pulses with millijoule-per-pulse energy at megahertz repetition when averaged over the ICF cycle. The secondary aperture is a 256-element phased gamma-ray array that coherently phases gamma bursts from individual Compton backscatter sources, enabling constructive interference at 20,000,000 km range — deep into the inner asteroid belt. A single Pulsar-equipped vessel holding station anywhere in the Earth-Moon system can sweep entire asteroid cluster populations across the inner belt, pre-qualifying ore bodies for future extraction missions without expending any transfer propellant. The combined instrument package characterises the complete elemental and mineralog­ic stratigraphy of any body in its field of view, from surface monolayer to 10 m depth. In surface deployment, 350 MW output drives simultaneous ice sublimation and electrolysis at 120 t/hr — enough to fill a large propellant depot tank in under a day. The Pulsar is named for the rotating neutron star that defines clockwork regularity in high-energy emission: a machine of immense power operating with absolute precision.
